Introduction

Osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) may effectively address thoracic spine dysfunction, relieving midback pain, improving respiratory mechanics, and enhancing overall thoracic mobility.  This article discusses thoracic spine anatomy, biomechanics, somatic dysfunctions, and OMT techniques.  The ribs and scoliosis are discussed in separate articles.

Thoracic vertebrae



The thoracic spine consists of 12 vertebrae (T1 through T12) with facets oriented primarily in the coronal plane, facilitating rotation, with limited flexion, extension, and sidebending.  Stability is provided by robust ligamentous structures, including the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments and intertransverse ligaments.



Thoracic curvature naturally forms a kyphotic alignment, optimizing spinal stability and facilitating load distribution.  Excessive kyphosis (hyperkyphosis) or hypomobility can lead to biomechanical dysfunction, chronic pain syndromes, and impaired respiratory function.  The thoracic vertebrae articulate with the ribs via costovertebral and costotransverse joints, which are crucial for thoracic cage stability and respiratory mechanics.

Anatomic landmarks



Scapular anatomic landmarks are useful for quickly identifying specific thoracic vertebrae during the diagnosis of thoracic vertebral somatic dysfunctions (

figure 1
):



  • The spine of the scapula is located at the level of the T3 spinous process.
  • The inferior angle of the scapula is located at the level of the T7 spinous process.


The spinous process can then be used to locate the transverse processes, allowing for segmental motion testing (ie, rotation, sidebending).  The location of the spinous process relative to the transverse processes varies in the thoracic spine (referred to as the "rule of threes"):



  • T1-T3 spinous process:  At the same level as the corresponding transverse processes.
  • T4-T6 spinous process:  Halfway between the corresponding transverse processes and the transverse processes of the vertebra below.
  • T7-T9 spinous process:  At the level of the transverse processes of the vertebra below.
  • T10-T12 spinous processes:
    • T10 spinous process:  At the level of the transverse processes of the vertebra below (T11).
    • T11 spinous process:  Halfway between the corresponding transverse processes (T11) and the transverse processes of the vertebra below (T12).
    • T12 spinous process:  At the same level as the corresponding transverse processes (T12).


Additional landmarks include the vena caval foramen (T8), esophageal hiatus (T10), and aortic hiatus (T12) (

figure 2
).

Thoracic spine disorders

Thoracic strain and sprain



Thoracic strains (muscular injury) and sprains (ligamentous injury) occur from trauma, poor posture, or repetitive movements.  They present with localized pain, muscle spasms, and restricted motion.  Palpation demonstrates hypertonicity and tenderness in paraspinal muscles (eg, trapezius, rhomboids, erector spinae).  OMT techniques such as soft tissue manipulation, myofascial release, and muscle energy technique can restore mobility and relieve pain.

Thoracic disc herniation



Thoracic disc herniation is uncommon but, if severe, may cause localized thoracic pain, radicular symptoms, and neurologic deficits.  Conservative management includes OMT to reduce paraspinal hypertonicity, improve vertebral mobility, and alleviate compressive symptoms using gentle techniques such as facilitated positional release and indirect myofascial release.

Thoracic vertebral somatic dysfunctions



Somatic dysfunctions in the thoracic spine present as restricted vertebral segment motion, typically involving rotation, flexion, or extension dysfunctions.  OMT techniques such as high-velocity, low-amplitude (HVLA) thrust and muscle energy technique effectively restore normal segmental movement.



HVLA thrust is a direct technique that moves the dysfunctional joint through its restrictive barrier to (ie, away from the direction that it is "stuck") by applying a rapid (high-velocity) and short (low-amplitude) thrust.  For thoracic dysfunctions, the "Kirksville crunch" is commonly used (

image 1
).

Summary



Osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) effectively addresses thoracic spine dysfunction by alleviating mid-back pain, enhancing respiratory mechanics, and improving thoracic mobility.  Understanding the biomechanics, anatomy, and key landmarks of the thoracic spine, including the scapular positioning (spine at T3, inferior angle at T7) and the "rule of threes" governing spinous process relationships, is important for accurate diagnosis and treatment.  Thoracic disorders—including strains/sprains, disc herniation, and vertebral somatic dysfunctions—present with restricted vertebral movements, myofascial tension, and paraspinal hypertonicity.  OMT techniques (eg, high-velocity, low-amplitude thrust; muscle energy technique) provide targeted and individualized management to restore normal segmental movement, enhance thoracic function, and reduce symptoms.
